text:
Can we just take a moment to appreciate that it takes 3 minutes and 26 seconds for this song to loop? And given that it was made in early 2000s how impressive that is?

 Or is it just me
author: Clutterfunky

text:
Probably not too impressive when you consider the songs are stored as midis (or a similar format) rather than actual audio files. The difference is like playing a cd vs having a musician sit in front of you and play off of sheet music; the instrument is a pre-programmed sound that's part of a "soundfont", the system itself is the musician, and the sheet music tells the musician how to play the song in real time. Because all you need to save are the "instruments" and "sheet music" the actual complex audio data that makes files like mp3 so big can be safely ignored, allowing you to get more bang for your buck in terms of storage.

Don't get me wrong, the amount of songs and their length are still impressive, but your comment seems to imply you think it was because of hardware storage limitations (for context, some guy ripped the midis for the sequel Explorers games and they come out at around 1.30 mb in size: https://psycommando.tumblr.com/post/105768826462/pok√©mon-mystery-dungeon-explorers-of-sky-full )
author: Atomic Robo Tesla

text:
Atomic Robo Tesla wow, I had no idea that‚Äôs how it used to work. Thanks for the information !
You can see just how far they pushed the limit of the old DS card with all these tricks. The game is barely between 50 and 100 MB if I recall correctly.
author: XxSpaceCakexX

text:
@XxSpaceCakexX Well it's not a trick, it's just how music used to work in games back then, even the original super mario theme and the donkey kong country tracks on the snes all use soundfont based music, it's just that the nes was limited to mostly beeping noises.

However, there are a number of ds games which use actual audio, but often the tracks are very compressed as a space saving measure (such as Elite Beat Agents or The World Ends With You) so they dont always have the best sound quality.

text:
An Average Pichu if i had to make a top 5 i think it would be:
5. Zinnia battle theme (OR/AS)
4. Dialga/Palkia battle theme (diamond/pearl)
3. Temporal Tower (PMD2)
2. Dialga's Fight to the Finish (PMD2)
Those 2 sound very similar but i think it's still important to separate them from each other because dialga's fight to the finish is extremely powerful and great because of that but temporal tower is so deep and emotional. when it starts playing after grovyle's death you feel like you're flying through the dungeon and that there's just no way to fail.
And the top step would go to sky tower as i said. this is so great. it's just complete. it has everything. the game came out 10 years ago and i'm still listening to it regularly. just incredible! it gives you hope, gives you that "one last time" or "let's finish this" feeling but has still such a great rhythm that you want to dance to it.
but of course 5 songs are far too few to acknowledge all the great pokemon soundtracks out there. even in the first mystery dungeon i could give you about 10 to 15 that are absolutely awesome. but as i said if i had to break it down to 5 these would be in it.
BTW have a look at the "dialga's fight to the finish remix" on the channel of LOrbSheddy. it's the best remix out there in my opinion :)

text: I remember the first time I heard this soundtrack in PMD:BRT, I was stunned at how intense yet delicate it was. It's incredible how at first listen it sounds very happy and joyful, but following the story, it carries a much deeper, somber note that just played with my emotions time and time again. The idea that you and your best friend were to venture where no one else could, to the sky, where you knew very well that it could be your last adventure, and that your return mattered not, was incredibly powerful. If you succeeded, the world continues. You and your best friend must save the world, at your own loss, and you know you won't make it back. To this day every time I listen to it, I remember the amount of times I had to repeat the dungeon to beat Rayquaza, but also that I didn't mind, because it gave me another opportunity to hear its fantastic music. I will admit that the first few times, it made me tear up, but I truly appreciate the incredible emotional influence that the story and track evoke. This soundtrack is simply magnificent. Nothing less.

author: DarkFlameZealot

text:
I'll tell you the feeling I got from this theme when I heard it. There is this certain sensation of inevitability and great scope to this song. In the story, you and your best friend are going into the world of the clouds, and you fully expect that you might never make it back alive. And yet, what you are doing is greater than yourselves. Whether you return or not doesn't matter because by succeeding, the WORLD will continue on. No one else can do what you are setting out to do. There's no turning back. This is why you've been brought to this world. It's time to save everyone by any means possible.

It's a testament to the absolutely unparalleled storytelling ability of all three of the Mystery Dungeon games (I say "three" not counting variants or the Wiiware PMD). I truly and wholeheartedly say that simply through the emotions of events like this, the PMD games have by far the most gripping and touching storylines I've EVER experienced in video games. And seeing as I've been around since the early days of the NES, that means something.
author: Ryusuta

text: Better words can not be spoken. People hate to see so many benevolent creatures so sad, which makes us cry even more.

I also cried very much during the dissappearance of my character at the Time Tower, in Explorers of the Sky.

But I just don't like the story of Gates to Infinity...Yes, I felt sad at the end of the story, but I can't even remember it. This was touching, but far less than the previouses games. I'm under the impression that they just have made another storyline with Kyurem, in order to respect the spirit of the PMD games, and then that's all. You can't even recruit all Pokemon like before. It's so much casualized that I had very fex fun playing it, and just a little sadness at the end. The only thing that I felt during the credits was nothing. I was just thinking "Am I not supposed to cry? Is it not sad?". But I think I couldn't identify myself with the character in the game. And this is what makes this game, in my point of view, the worst of the three PMDs.

text:
You are climbing up a tower made of clouds in an attempt to save a world that is not your own, with the realization that you shall have to leave your new best friend and everything you can remember, into a world that knows you but remains a mystery to you. A realization that no matter that even if you can stay, everyone who ever knew you in one world will miss you forever. This sorrow is what makes this music the most important piece of music I have heard in my life.
Fact.

text:
This is the only thing that I feel PMD 2 was missing.  Near the end of the story, an overall soothing and relaxing tune but with a tense melody to represent the finality, the game's story drawing to a close.
Just listen.  It starts out so calm, almost like music you would use in a dream. It gradually transitions to that tenseness primarily by slowly adding more instruments.  It all comes together in an epic climax.  Yet the tempo always stays pretty slow, keeping that relaxed feeling.
Brilliant.
